Non-intrusive load monitoring is a promising technology in intelligent energy consumption management, which can provide insights for electricity use patterns and customer living habits, leading to the technical support of multiple smart energy use applications. As the most challenging problem in this specific field, the real time load disaggregation with simultaneous switching operations still remains unsolved due to its complexity and uncertainty. In this paper, a practical and feasible solution for the simultaneous action problems under real time non-intrusive load monitoring framework is proposed and investigated, which is capable of filling such research gap. At the first stage, to tackle the different kinds of overlapping combinations, an adaptive-window based detection approach is applied to capture the state changes. Secondly, a deep dictionary learning model is proposed in the real time load monitoring architecture, where the dictionary atom is generated in a semi-supervised modularization way and extended with high order dynamic features of appliances. Then, sparse coding formulized algorithm is presented to solve the problem, which is compatible of handling simultaneous occurrence of multiple switching events. The proposed model and algorithm are tested and verified in both simulation platform and field measurements. Results show that the operation-overlapping issue can be effectively addressed by the presented method, in addition to the high accuracy monitoring performance. Keywords Dynamic features Machine learning Real time load disaggregation Simultaneous switching events Sparse coding 1 Introduction As the key to sustainable development, energy related problems have always been the hot topics all over the world. The worldwide energy demand and consumption have been dramatically increased along with the fast growth of global economy. Based on the policies of major governments and organizations, the International Energy Agency projected that the global energy demand in 2040 would increase by 25% compared with 2018, while the electricity demand would increase by 58% [1]. Since the electricity consumption accounts for an increasing proportion in total energy consumption, effective power usage management would contribute to the energy conservation and renewable energy utilization. Therefore, the related electric power management technologies have emerged as efficient energy-issue solutions and drawn wide attentions. Specifically, building load is the world’s largest power consumption terminal, accounting for more than 40% electricity consumption on average in developed countries [2], even 76% in United States [3]. Therefore, the electricity managements focusing on the building power load have high academic value and industrial potentials, becoming the hot issues of the current international research forefront. One hotspot is the demand response (DR) technology, which utilizes the flexibility of specific loads to help with the distributed renewable energy utilization and provide ancillary services for distribution network. By realizing demand response, the energy users are moving closer to intelligence. Nevertheless, the flexible loads for DR are specific to certain electric appliances, so sensing the operation states of these appliance states is the prerequisite of demand response implementation. As an effective method to analyze the power load characteristics and evaluate the real time appliance states of buildings, non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) technology, originated from professor Hart in MIT [4], aims at monitoring the appliance states and power through the single electric meter installed at the customer entrance. NILM technology uses disaggregation algorithms instead of sensor networks in intrusive load monitoring, which is more simplified, economic, and reliable [5]. Besides, the appliance usage information could be provided without interfering the occupants’ normal life, which is more acceptable by customers and highly desired from the demand response view. In addition to the distributed renewable energy utilization from demand response view, the energy conservation awareness of residents would also be enhanced by understanding their own power usage patterns, which is essential for energy sustainable development. In summary, NILM is a potential technical basis to support the implementation of energy user intelligence. Hence, various researches have been conducted in this field, especially for the disaggregation model and algorithm studies towards credible load detections and practical applications [6]. For credible load detections, two research directions have been investigated to achieve precise and accurate NILM performance, i.e., load signatures and disaggregation algorithms. Started from [4], the real power and reactive power are treated as the most typical steady state load signatures [7], and have been widely explored [8]. Furthermore, since different kinds of electric appliances have unique harmonics [9], the frequency domain features have been utilized with good performance [10]. The higher the sampling rate, the more information we can use to identify the appliance, where V-I trajectory [11], voltage/current/power transients based on Fryze’s Time-Domain Power Theory [12] or S-transform [13], and phase noises [14] are representative signatures of such research. Basically, the use of high-resolution based load signatures can improve the overall NILM performance, at the expense of higher requirements of metering and processing devices. The investigation of disaggregation algorithms is the other field that researchers focus to enhancing NILM results, in which pattern recognition is considered as a more promising direction than traditional mathematic optimization. Based on whether the attributes of the learning appliances are known or not, the algorithms can be categorized into three classes, which are supervised learning [15], unsupervised learning [16], and semi-supervised learning [17], respectively. With the development of machine learning and deep learning, there emerges quantities of potential NILM algorithms from pattern recognition. Classification, the simplest machine learning algorithm, has been deeply researched in NILM, including K-means or C-means classification [18], multi-label classification [19], neuro-fuzzy classification [20], etc. Similarly, as a typical unsupervised learning approach, clustering is also widely used [21], even in the initial research [4]. Filtering algorithm is another promising approach dealing with NILM problem, while background filtering [22], particle filtering [23], and characteristic filtering [24] have been discussed. Considering the sequential features of appliance operation in NILM, the Markov model have been introduced at the early stage to extract the operation patterns from time series [25]. In particular, the Factorial Hidden Markov Model has been proven as a feasible approach for appliance operation forecasting and analysis [26]. Other data mining technologies, such as Convolutional Neural Networks [27], Wavelet Transform [28], Graph Signal Processing [29], and Spatiotemporal Pattern Network [30], have been studied in NILM problems. In general, the explorations of pattern recognition algorithms have achieved remarkable outcomes, leading to the satisfied accuracy over 90% under specific circumstances. However, the ultimate goal of NILM studies is to form a feasible alternative solution to take place of sensor network, and provide insights of specific loads states for intelligent energy use managements in real life. So the practicability of related research becomes an important concern from the engineering application perspective. Especially due to the perfect detection accuracy achieved in past studies, researchers started to transfer their focus to integrate NILM technologies into field applications. In Ref. [6], the idea of using real power only as the load signature has been surveyed, which is a potential way that highly simplifies measurement and storage requirements of field devices. Similarly, Ref. [31] have deeply investigated the practical NILM solutions for low-rate aggregation data, which are more compatible with existing metering systems, so as to [32]. Considering the fluctuant voltage supply at distribution network end-users, [33] proposed a robust solution based on Karhunen-Loève expansion and fast deconvolution, efficiently addressing the varying voltage issues. In order to tackle the identical or similar appliances belonging to the same kind of group, [34] initialized the NILM study for a group of appliances, effectively solving the problem of multi-similar appliance monitoring. In summary, some efforts have already been made to fill the gap between academic research and practical applications, but there still exist some barriers. Targeting at the real time NILM, which is appropriate for the demand response, the simultaneous switching operations in event-based monitoring is of great challenge. The simultaneous occurrence of multiple switching events is common in real life, but rarely investigated in research. In early studies, the detected operations are assumed to be non-overlapped with each other, i.e., one detected event only contains one switching operation. However, this assumption is not consistent with the real appliance operations, generating false detections when applying to field practice. Under the trend towards practical NILM applications, handling overlapped switching operations emerges as a valuable and urgent topic. Some studies did realize the importance of addressing overlapping operations in NILM problem, e.g. [3], [7], [12], [21], [25] and [29]. Nevertheless, the overlapping issue is only mentioned or briefly discussed in these studies, but not intensively investigated and tackled to our knowledge. In response to above observations, this paper initializes a thorough study on the real time NILM with overlapping issues. Firstly, the overlapping problem is explicitly discussed based on the real time event detection framework, and a dynamic event-window approach is presented to address the complexity and uncertainty of temporal combinations. On the basis of event window extractions, an enhanced dictionary learning based method is proposed to formulize the NILM model and solutions. Although dictionary learning methods have already been investigated in NILM problem [35], it is the first attempt to be coped with event-based real time monitoring problem to our knowledge. Such new utilization is challengeable, and realized by enhancing the dictionary learning from both model and solution views. In the model part, deep features of appliance, such as high order dynamics, are modularized in the dictionary atom in a semi-supervised way. In the solution part, the uncertain sequential shift of overlapped operations is handled by extending the dictionary atom with sparse coding principle. The use of high order dynamics and sequential shift of appliance patterns makes the dictionary more informative and essential, which is defined as Deep Dictionary Learning (DDL) in this paper. The proposed method is firstly verified on the Low Voltage Network Simulation (LVNS) platform [36], and then tested by NILM public datasets. In addition to solving the overlapping issue, the proposed approach also achieves credible detection results with flexible load signature utilization, proving to be a practical solution for various NILM based intelligent energy management applications. The major contribution of this study is the presence of a robust real time monitoring approach, which is able to address the simultaneous switching operations of diverse appliances. In other words, the assumption that one detected event contains only one switching operation is no longer required in NILM studies, making NILM research more consistent with the practical situations. Therefore, the proposed real time monitoring approach provides a practical basis for the implementation of demand response, and can enhance the intelligence of the energy users. Detailed technical contributions can be summarized as: • The operation overlapping issue in practical NILM applications is thoroughly discussed and addressed, while the gap between research and implementation is filled. • Dictionary learning approach is applied for the real time NILM problem for the first time, and enhanced by extending the atoms with high order dynamics and sequential shift design. • Sparse-coding based approach is proposed to solve the presented model, which is consistent with the principle dealing with overlapping issues in NILM. • The usage of load signatures is flexible in the proposed model, leading to the practicability for existing smart metering systems. • The proposed model and approach are verified by both simulation platform and field measurements, achieving outstanding load monitoring accuracy in addition to the capability of distinguishing simultaneous switching operations of electrical appliances. The proposed dictionary learning based model and solution are formulized in Section 3. In Section 4, experiments based on simulation platform and filed measurements are analyzed. Conclusions are drawn in Section 5. 2 Problem statement Real time load disaggregation is an important branch of NILM research, which is the technical basis of power demand response and intelligent energy use managements. The event-based appliance monitoring is immensely popular, and only needs to do the analysis while detecting the changes of integrated readings, which is free of computational burden. Besides, the background noise can be naturally eliminated during the event extraction period, resulting in the robustness under noisy signals. In addition to above advantages, the intermediate state changes of both multi-state loads and continuous varying loads could also be modelled as common switching operation, indicating the compatibility of event-based methods. Dissimilarity of electrical features of appliance switching operations is the premise of such method. Technically speaking, event-based appliance monitoring belongs to the pattern recognition field, and the mathematic model can be described as (1) P ← find P i i ∈ [ 1 , N ] where P is the detected event signal, {•} is the mathematic set symbol, Pi is the ith electrical feature of appliance switching operation, N is the total electrical feature number. Above formulation is based on the assumption that no overlapping issue happens, resulting from the consideration that switch operation of most appliances is an instantaneous behavior. Although rarely, the overlapping does happen when multiple occupants operate different appliances at the same time, e.g. the mother switches on the toaster when the child turns off the TV and goes to kitchen for breakfast, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). What is more common is that these two behaviors are slightly stagger, but the interval is too short to distinguish, leading to one detected event, seen in Fig. 1(b). Such appliances need a so called “event window” to capture all electrical features, which is proved to be an effective idea for event analysis [37]. Particularly for multi-state appliances, the transients among diverse operation states are also treated as common change behaviors, which are modelled together with other switching operations. However, in order to handle the problem features, each step is customized with specific approaches, forming an effective solution. 3.1 Event detection with adaptive dynamic window The window length T of detected event is an important parameter in (3). It directly determines the possibility of β calculation in (4). However, as illustrated in Fig. 1, the window length could be as short as several second (in Fig. 1(a)), or as long as one minute (in Fig. 1(d)). Though a large constant window could be applied to cover all situations, some disadvantages appear. For example, a long window could contain more independent switching operations, which is inconsistent with the overlapping definitions in Section 2, as well as the sparse coding principle in the following part. Therefore, an adaptive dynamic window idea is proposed and utilized in this study. Such implementation also provides additional benefits, e.g. if the detected window length is short, it indicates there is no long continuous operation in detected event. In detail, the event detection with adaptive dynamic window can be processed by the following procedures: • If change happens, use window of length Tste to identify the beginning steady state and ending steady state of the event, where Tste is the time index for steady state confirmation. • Denote the duration time between these two steady states as Tope , and calculate the total window length as T = 2Tste + Tope . • Extract the information located in the T time range, and form the detected event. Based on these, the detected event includes three parts: initial steady state, changes due to switching operations, and final steady state. The length is determined by the switching operation duration. 3.2 Feature extraction using deep dictionary learning The formulation (3) can be expressed as the total signal consisting of several individual compositions, which exactly matches the idea of dictionary learning. Therefore, this learning method is introduced, and modified to form a practical and applicable approach. 3.2.1 Dictionary learning approach Define D = [ d 1, d 2,…, d N ] ∈ R T × N as the dictionary, and each column d k ∈ R T ×1 as an atom. Given a target signal x ∈ R T ×1, the problem is defined as dictionary learning if following linear combination establishes (5) x = D · α where α ∈ R N ×1 and should be as sparse as possible. A key criterion to evaluate the dictionary learning model is the sparsity of parameter α . However, in real time NILM problem presented in (3), the occurrence matrix is binary, resulting in a discrete calculation model. Compared with traditional dictionary learning solution model in (6), such formulation shows potential for simplification. Therefore, in order to take full advantage of this, a semi-supervised modularization approach with high order dynamic characteristics of monitored appliances is proposed. Compared with conventional dictionary learning, the presented model is special on three aspects: 1) There are three dictionaries and three atom models, i.e., time series, normalized first order difference, and spike sequence of second order difference. 2) The atom is initialized based on the physical features of individual switching operation, which is referred as featured operation in this work. 3) Since the occurrence matrix α should be as sparse as possible and the sparsest form is α“ , the high order occurrence matrices α' and α” can help with the initialization of α . Extract the featured operations from training dataset via data cleaning and clustering. The database for individual operations is formed. • Step 2. Use adaptive dynamic window-based approach to extract the real time monitoring event. The event length is determined. • Step 3. Initialize the dictionary atoms via Eq. Implement (10) to iteratively optimize the dictionary and occurrence matrix, until the best fitting is achieved. • Step 5. Analyze the calculated occurrence matrix and find the switching appliances. Based on these procedures, the implementation flow of proposed real time NILM approach is illustrated in Fig. 4 . There are two main blocks in the proposed method, i.e., supervised data and dictionary initialization and unsupervised dictionary update and sparse coding. There are several points need to be clarified. First of all, in the proposed model (9) and solution (10), multiple electrical features, such as real power (P), reactive power (Q) and harmonics (H) can be utilized. And of course, the more features are used, the better the detection performance. However, to cope with the field measurement constraints, the proposed approach achieves satisfactory accuracy even with only real power analysis, indicating the good scalability of the proposed approach. Secondly, the initial feature library P ¯ i , i.e., the original switching operation database, is generated following the electrical characteristics during the training phase. Although sub-meters can be used to obtain the dataset of switching operation signals, in this work the quantities of dataset are extracted by applying the adaptive window approach on the integrated training signals. And the corresponding tags indicating the correlation between event and appliance are also labelled. By applying clustering to the dataset for each appliance, the featured operations are extracted. Once the monitoring object is determined, the featured operations for individual appliances are also fixed. For newly added appliance, the training procedure is necessary before implementing real time monitoring. The appliance feature uncertainty, caused by the appliance noise or background noise as well as the measurement error, is diminished by the use of high order patterns. Last but not least, the unsupervised update of dictionary atoms focuses on the uncertainty of overlapping time, leading to a feasible solution for the overlapping issue. However, if there is no overlapping issue in detected event, then the number of non-zero element in α is one, and t is no longer to be optimized. Such calculation is quite computationally friendly, which also achieves satisfactory accuracy for traditional monitoring problem. 4 Case studies The evaluation metrics are provided first in this section, where common metrics are introduced and adjusted to tackle overlapping problems. Therefore, event accuracy is defined first to evaluate the event-based monitoring performance. (11) A e = C O e C O e + W O e × 100 % where e ∈ Ωe, Ωe is the set of all extracted events. Traditional precision, sensitivity, and F-measure are the most commonly used accuracy metrics for event-based NILM evaluation [38]. Such results indicate that the proposed approach is robust for demand response utilizations, where large power appliances are more concerned. 5 Conclusion In this paper, a comprehensive study dealing with simultaneous actions under real time non-intrusive load monitoring framework is investigated. At the first stage, the problem formulation is established based on the consideration of overlapping characteristics. Secondly, deep dictionary learning approach is proposed to utilize the dynamic features in real time monitoring. Lastly, a systematic solution following sparse coding principle is proposed. The whole study is verified on both simulation platform and field measurements. Results show that events with overlapped switching operations do exist in real life. The proposed study not only handles the overlapping issue well, but also achieves satisfied performance in common load monitoring. With the robust real time monitoring approach proposed in this work, the event based non-intrusive load monitoring studies are no longer constrained by the assumption that one change event only contains a single switching operation. Therefore, an important gap between theoretical study and practical applications is filled, leading to the practical implementations of advanced load managements. In conclusion, the proposed study provides an effective technical route to support the implementation of energy user intelligence. In particular, the potential smart energy use applications based on this study are diverse, including but not limited to the following fields: • Real time demand response. By monitoring the specific switching behaviors of flexible resource appliances, the real time response capability can be analyzed timely and response instructions can be issued precisely. • Abnormal energy consumption alarm. The continuous monitoring for a certain user can distinguish the abnormal energy consumption and sound the alarm in time, such as finding an appliance that is turned on for too long time. • Energy habit improvement. Once an improper energy behavior is detected, timely feedbacks to the occupants can help them to improve their energy habits. coredata.dc:description: Non-intrusive load monitoring is a promising technology in intelligent energy consumption management, which can provide insights for electricity use patterns and customer living habits, leading to the technical support of multiple smart energy use applications. As the most challenging problem in this specific field, the real time load disaggregation with simultaneous switching operations still remains unsolved due to its complexity and uncertainty. In this paper, a practical and feasible solution for the simultaneous action problems under real time non-intrusive load monitoring framework is proposed and investigated, which is capable of filling such research gap. At the first stage, to tackle the different kinds of overlapping combinations, an adaptive-window based detection approach is applied to capture the state changes. Secondly, a deep dictionary learning model is proposed in the real time load monitoring architecture, where the dictionary atom is generated in a semi-supervised modularization way and extended with high order dynamic features of appliances. Then, sparse coding formulized algorithm is presented to solve the problem, which is compatible of handling simultaneous occurrence of multiple switching events. The proposed model and algorithm are tested and verified in both simulation platform and field measurements. Results show that the operation-overlapping issue can be effectively addressed by the presented method, in addition to the high accuracy monitoring performance.
